items.title: A Crisis Deferred
items.excerpt: Early in Harriet Jacobs’s memoir, Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl, Jacobs receives a new pair of shoes from her grandmother in time for a February snowstorm, only for the mistress of the household to make her take them off. The mistress—jealous of her husband’s lecherous…

items.title: A Knock at the Door
items.excerpt: “Hello.” The voice I heard when I picked up the phone on Election Day was low, leaden, and remote, as if spoken from a crypt. “This is Andrew Cuomo.” It was a recorded message urging me to vote. Even as his speech quickened—the city must “move forward ,” he said, with rising e…

items.title: Wave of Domination
items.excerpt: What this weekend’s strikes on Iran clarify is that the post–October 7 period has marked the terminal phase of the liberal international order. For eight decades since the end of World War II, the set of economic, political, diplomatic, and legal arrangements that make up the …

items.title: Sympathy and Indifference
items.excerpt: A woman and a man face each other across a cafe table.

items.title: The Ephemeral Nature of Everything Good
items.excerpt: Brian Wilson, who died last week nine days shy of his 83rd birthday, was called “child-like” for much of his adult life, and his band’s music will probably be associated with innocence (the makers’, the listeners’, and America’s: all lost) for as long as their recordings endur…

items.title: Perfume Genius
items.excerpt: In matters of style, diligence is usually understood to be antithetical to spontaneity. This is the conventional wisdom when it comes to cinematic style too, and among viewers in the West, Japanese cinema in particular tends to be thought of as the effusive outpouring of maver…

items.title: Two Days Talking to People Looking for Jobs at ICE
items.excerpt: For two days in June, I attended a Department of Homeland Security job fair at the Dulles Expo Center in Chantilly, Virginia. I learned about the event while browsing the DHS website in order to find the phone number of someone who’d been detained by Immigration and Customs En…

items.title: At Immigration Court
items.excerpt: M texted me from the adjacent bedroom at 8 AM: “Wake up.” In the kitchen, he combed out his beard and ate a banana, which his people’s warriors ate to feel full, he told me. I pointed to a stray hair that stuck out of the side of his neck. “I keep meaning to pluck it,” he said.

items.title: Tell It Slanted
items.excerpt: STEPHEN PICCARELLA: Do you think it’s possible to make an honest movie about a band like Pavement, and if so, how?
